name: Linkin Park
description:
'''Linkin Park''' is an American [[Rock music|rock]] band formed in [[Agoura Hills, California]], in 1996. The band's current lineup consists of vocalist/rhythm guitarist/keyboardist [[Mike Shinoda]], lead guitarist [[Brad Delson]], DJ/turntablist [[Joe Hahn]], bassist [[Dave Farrell]], vocalist [[Emily Armstrong]], and drummer [[Colin Brittain]]. The lineup for the band's first seven studio albums included lead vocalist [[Chester Bennington]] and drummer [[Rob Bourdon]]; after Bennington's death in July 2017, the band endured a seven-year hiatus, during which Bourdon chose to depart from the band. In September 2024, Linkin Park's reformation was announced along with the addition of Armstrong and Brittain.

Categorized mainly as [[alternative rock]] and [[nu metal]], Linkin Park's earlier music spanned a fusion of [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] and [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], with their later music featuring more [[electronica]] and [[Pop music|pop]] elements. Linkin Park rose to international fame with their debut studio album, ''[[Hybrid Theory]]'' (2000), which became certified [[RIAA certification#List of certifications|Diamond]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). Released during the peak of the nu metal scene, the album's singles' heavy airplay on [[MTV]] led to the singles "[[One Step Closer (Linkin Park song)|One Step Closer]]", "[[Crawling (song)|Crawling]]", and "[[In the End]]" all charting highly on the US [[Mainstream Rock (chart)|Mainstream Rock]] chart. The lattermost also [[Crossover music|crossed over]] to the number two spot on the nation's [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. Their second album, ''[[Meteora (album)|Meteora]]'' (2003), continued the band's success. The band explored [[Experimental music|experimental]] sounds on their third album, ''[[Minutes to Midnight (Linkin Park album)|Minutes to Midnight]]'' (2007). By the end of the decade, Linkin Park was among the most successful and popular rock acts.

The band continued to explore a wider variation of musical types on their fourth album, ''[[A Thousand Suns]]'' (2010), layering their music with more [[Electronic music|electronic]] sounds. The band's fifth album, ''[[Living Things (Linkin Park album)|Living Things]]'' (2012), combined musical elements from all of their previous records. Their sixth album, ''[[The Hunting Party (album)|The Hunting Party]]'' (2014), returned to a heavier rock sound, while their seventh album, ''[[One More Light]]'' (2017), was a substantially more pop-oriented record. The band's eighth album, ''[[From Zero]]'' (2024), returned to more of their original sound while also incorporating musical elements from all of their previous records.

Linkin Park is among both the best-selling bands of the 21st century and the [[List of best-selling music artists|world's best-selling music artists]], having sold over 100 million records worldwide. They have won two [[Grammy Award]]s, six [[American Music Awards]], four [[Billboard Music Award|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], four [[MTV Video Music Award]]s, 10 [[MTV Europe Music Award]]s, and three [[World Music Awards]]. In 2003, [[MTV2]] named Linkin Park the sixth-greatest band of the music video era and the third-best of the new millennium. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' ranked Linkin Park No. 19 on the Best Artists of the Decade list. In 2012, the band was voted as the greatest artist of the 2000s in a Bracket Madness poll on [[VH1]]. In 2014, the band was declared "the Biggest Rock Band in the World Right Now" by ''[[Kerrang!]]''.
